In legal terms, "common law" refers to legal principles established by judges (in their written opinions) which have the effect of law (and can only be overridden by a higher appellate court or by the Legislature).  In marital terms, "common law" refers to the legal presumption that a man and wife who have cohabitated (lived together) and substantially established a life together are essentially married for all intents and purposes.  This is now the law in only a minority of states.  It was designed to prevent the injustice that occurs when couples disband and the lack of formality causes one party to be cheated out of an equitable share of their joint possessions and assets.

Nowadays, with GPS and diving robots, it is possible to locate where exactly certain position markers are located. Every year, North America and Europe drift apart a few centimetres, and GPS coordinates will have to add another correction. Luckily, neither North America nor the Old World as isolated systems move that fast, so that the regionalized reference systems remain valid. But if you manage to measure a location each in America and Europe to the sub-centimetre, you will notice the change in the last digits of the raw GPS coordinates within very few years.

The comment regarding pregnant women having contact with cat litter has nothing to do with cancer; it reflects concern over a disease called toxoplasmosis. One common source of the infection is cat feces, either in litter boxes or in soil contaminated by infected cats who wander outdoors.  If a woman contracts the infection for the first time while pregnant, it can reach the baby, possibly causing miscarriage, brain damage, or other serious illness.
